Paper Exercise

If \(\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\ldots \lambda_n\) are the eigenvalues of a matrix \(A,\), get a piece of paper and prove the following:

  1. \(A^T\) has eigenvalues \(\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\ldots \lambda_n\).

  2. If \(A\) is upper triangular, then its eigenvalues are exactly the main diagonal entries.

  3. The inverse matrix \(A^{-1}\) has eigenvalues \({{1\over \lambda_1}},\ {{1\over \lambda_2}},\ldots {{1\over \lambda_n}}\).

  4. The matrix \(A-kI\) has eigenvalues \(\lambda_1-k,\lambda_2-k,\ldots \lambda_n-k\).

  5. (Harder) The matrix \(A^2\) has eigenvalues \(\lambda_1^2,\lambda_2^2,\ldots \lambda_n^2\).

  6. (Harder) The matrix \(A^k\) (\(k\) a non-negative integer) has eigenvalues \(\lambda_1^k,\lambda_2^k,\ldots \lambda_n^k.\)

N.B. Some of these results are useful in the numerical calculation of eigenvalues. 

We give the solution on the next page. Please try to complete the problem before referencing the solution.
